title: Laboratory Based Soft X-ray Microscopy at a Core Facility
content: Analysis of three-dimensional biological cell samples is critical for understanding the mechanisms of viral disease and for developing novel therapeutics. Soft x-ray tomography (SXT), employing low energy X-rays (E ∼500 eV) in the so called ‘water-window’, is the unique technology that can image whole intact cells in 3D under normal and pathological conditions without labelling or fixation, at high throughput and spatial resolution [1-4]. The main challenge of SXM is that the photonic illumination required for imaging has heretofore only been available at synchrotron labs [5].
